statements.174: User data should be treated as a public trust—collected only when necessary, secured with strong, auditable protections, and governed by clear, plain-language consent and easy controls that let people access, correct, or delete their information. Practical oversight—independent audits, timely breach notifications, privacy-by-design, and proportionate consequences, with special safeguards for students and other vulnerable groups—can balance innovation with equity and rebuild confidence that technology serves communities rather than exploits them.
statements.670: Tech companies should steward user data as an entrusted family matter: limit collection to what is necessary, secure it with strong safeguards, and provide plain-language, easy controls so parents and children can confidently manage privacy. Common-sense, enforceable standards—privacy-by-design, independent audits, timely breach notification, and proportional penalties—will balance innovation with accountability and rebuild public trust.
statements.737: Tech companies should steward user data with the care expected of community institutions: collect only what is necessary, secure it robustly, and provide clear, plain-language controls so families and vulnerable users—especially children—can make informed choices. Balancing innovation with accountability requires privacy-by-design, independent audits, enforceable remedies for misuse, and policies that permit beneficial research while protecting individual dignity and public trust.
statements.224: Tech companies should treat user data as a public trust, embedding privacy-by-design into products by minimizing collection, securing information with strong encryption, and offering clear, plain-language controls for consent, access, portability, and deletion. Special protections for children and students, independent oversight, and enforceable accountability will allow innovation to continue while preserving dignity and community well-being, creating usable defaults and transparent practices that let educators, families, regulators, and businesses find common ground.
statements.742: User data deserves the same duty of care as medical records and household privacy: collect only what is necessary, embed privacy-by-design and robust, auditable security, and provide clear, plain-language tools for consent, access, portability, and deletion. Reasonable, enforceable standards and independent oversight—paired with the option to share responsibly de-identified data for public benefit—create a practical balance that protects families and vulnerable people while allowing innovation to serve the community.
statements.45: User data should be stewarded with the same rigor as sensitive medical records: minimized, secured with strong encryption and access controls, and shared only with clear, meaningful consent and independent oversight. Practical measures—privacy-by-design, simple user controls for access, portability and deletion, timely breach notifications, and proportionate accountability—can reconcile the benefits of innovation with protection for vulnerable people and the public trust that sustains useful services.
statements.800: Data stewardship should be disciplined and practical: collect only what is necessary, secure it with strong safeguards, and provide clear, easy-to-use controls so individuals and communities can participate with confidence. Combining privacy-by-design, independent oversight, and proportionate regulation creates common ground that preserves innovation, protects vulnerable people, and holds companies accountable for misuse.
statements.253: User data should be treated like a cherished sketchbook—collected sparingly, secured with rigor, and shared only with clear, plain-language consent that people can easily understand and control. Practical safeguards—privacy-by-design, independent oversight, accessible controls, and proportionate accountability—can balance innovation with dignity and protect the most vulnerable while letting creative, beneficial technologies endure.
statements.132: A practical, family-first and creative outlook argues that tech companies should treat user data as a trusted responsibility: collect only what is necessary, secure it robustly, and explain uses in plain language so people of all backgrounds can make informed choices. Balancing innovation with enforceable accountability—privacy-by-design, meaningful consent and remedies, independent audits, and special protections for children—creates common ground that preserves useful services while protecting dignity, safety, and community trust.
statements.104: User data must be treated as a public trust: collect only what is necessary, secure it with rigorous safeguards, and explain uses in plain, enforceable terms so people can make informed choices. Practical oversight—regular independent audits, clear remedies for misuse, and sensible regulation—will balance public safety and innovation while holding companies accountable to the communities they serve.
statements.739: Personal data should be treated as a public trust: collect only what is necessary, protect it with strong security and encryption, explain uses in plain, accessible language, and provide simple, meaningful controls for consent, access, correction, portability, and deletion—especially for health, family, and other sensitive information. Reasonable regulation, independent audits, timely breach notification, and proportionate penalties can preserve space for responsible innovation while ensuring accountability and protecting vulnerable communities, restoring the practical trust needed to rely on digital services.
statements.202: Technology firms should steward personal data with the same care entrusted to educators and caregivers: collect only what is necessary, secure it rigorously, and provide clear, plain-language controls so families and learners can understand and manage their information. Embedding privacy-by-design, independent oversight, meaningful remedies, and pathways for responsibly governed, de-identified research offers a practical balance that protects vulnerable people while allowing innovation to improve public services.
statements.667: User data should be stewarded with the same care given to personal confidences—collected only as needed, secured rigorously, and explained in plain, accessible language so everyone can understand and act. Practical responsibilities include meaningful consent, simple controls for access, portability, and deletion, special protections for children and vulnerable people, independent oversight, and proportionate accountability, enabling innovation that serves communities rather than exploits them. This balanced, care-driven approach preserves dignity and public trust while allowing responsibly governed uses of data for research and better services.
statements.648: Tech companies should treat user data as a community trust—collecting only what is necessary, protecting it with strong security, and explaining practices in plain language so people of all abilities can understand and exercise real control. Balancing innovation with enforceable safeguards like privacy-by-design, independent oversight, timely breach notification, and accessible remedies will protect vulnerable neighbors and families while allowing useful services to continue.
statements.781: Years spent tinkering with old electronics and volunteering in the community shape a practical ethic: tech companies must steward user data like entrusted property—collecting only what is necessary, securing it rigorously, and explaining uses in plain language so everyone can make informed choices. Practical safeguards—data minimization, strong encryption, meaningful consent, accessible controls, timely breach notification, and independent oversight—balance personal dignity and public safety while enabling legitimate innovation. Special protections for children, people with disabilities, and low-income users foster trust and ensure technology serves the common good.
statements.67: Personal stories encoded in data deserve the same respect as cherished narratives: collect only what is necessary, secure it with strong safeguards, and give individuals clear, plain-language controls to access, correct, or delete their information. Practical, enforceable measures—privacy-by-design, independent audits, meaningful remedies, and narrowly defined allowances for de-identified research—can balance innovation with community dignity and safety so technology serves the public good.
